Left: view of helical metal chains with opposite handedness; right: the one-dimensional hexagonal channel with a diameter of 6.8 Å considering the van der Waals radius; (c) space-filling view of the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> along the [001] direction; (d) topological features of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displayed by tiling. Color code: carbon: gray; nitrogen: blue; oxygen: red; cadmium: green. elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">A luminescent 3D metal-organic framework, [CdL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·1DMF·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, L = 1-(4-carboxyphenyl)-5-methyl-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole-3-carboxylic acid, DMF = <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide), has been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The overall structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains hexagonal channels and is constructed by helical SBUs with <ce:bold>etb</ce:bold> topology. Interestingly, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits good fluorescence intensity in DMF and can be quenched by trace amounts of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions. The Ksv values of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> towards Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>can reach up to 3.5 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> which surpass some MOFs materials. More importantly, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is also a recyclable luminescent sensor which can be potentially applied in detecting Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A luminescent 3D metal-organic framework, [CdL(H2O)]⋅1DMF⋅1.5H2O (1, L=1-(4-carboxyphenyl)-5-methyl-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole-3-carboxylic acid, DMF=N,N-dimethylformamide), has been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The overall structure of 1 contains hexagonal channels and is constructed by helical SBUs with etb topology. Interestingly, compound 1 exhibits good fluorescence intensity in DMF and can be quenched by trace amounts of Fe3+ ions. The Ksv values of compound 1 towards Fe3+can reach up to 3.5×104 which surpass some MOFs materials. More importantly, compound 1 is also a recyclable luminescent sensor which can be potentially applied in detecting Fe3+.

elements.content:

Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a recyclable luminescent sensor and exhibits high performance for detecting Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>.<ce:display>

Graphical abstract

A luminescent Cd-based metal-organic framework (compound 1) has been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Compound 1 is a recyclable luminescent sensor and exhibits high performance for detecting Fe3+.  Unlabelled Image

<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="li0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">A luminescent 3D Cd-based MOF has been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="li0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has helical SBUs and hexagonal channels which can improve detecting performance.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="li0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a recyclable luminescent sensor for effectively detecting Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> in DMF solution.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ A luminescent 3D Cd-based MOF has been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized.   ⋅ Compound 1 has helical SBUs and hexagonal channels which can improve detecting performance.   ⋅ Compound 1 is a recyclable luminescent sensor for effectively detecting Fe3+ in DMF solution.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">A luminescent 3D Cd-based MOF has been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has helical SBUs and hexagonal channels which can improve detecting performance.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a recyclable luminescent sensor for effectively detecting Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> in DMF solution.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which possess large surface area, tunable pore size and chemical tenability, have received great attention from academia and industry alike on account of their potential applications in gas adsorption and separation, luminescent sensing, catalysis, nonlinear optics, magnetic applications, and so on []. Recently, luminescent metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) have been considered as a type of burgeoning materials for biological and chemical detection because of their obvious advantages, such as fast and high sensitivity, low cost, and facile manipulation []. For example, Li's group have reported two highly stable fluorescent Zr(IV)-based MOFs, BUT-14 and BUT-15 [], which exhibit potentially practical values in monitoring/sensing Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions in water, as well as in biological systems. Another fascinating example, BUT-12 and BUT-13 reported by Zhou and Li et al. can be prospective candidates for detecting and removal of antibiotics and organic explosives in water []. The common point of two works is the high porosities of the synthesized LMOFs materials which allow the preconcentration of the target analytes in their pores, thus increasing the detecting performance. Therefore, design and synthesis LMOFs materials with large pores is an effective way to improve the sensing ability of such materials [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
A luminescent 3D Cd-based MOF has been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized.

Compound 1 has helical SBUs and hexagonal channels which can improve detecting performance.

Compound 1 is a recyclable luminescent sensor for effectively detecting Fe3+ in DMF solution.

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which possess large surface area, tunable pore size and chemical tenability, have received great attention from academia and industry alike on account of their potential applications in gas adsorption and separation, luminescent sensing, catalysis, nonlinear optics, magnetic applications, and so on []. Recently, luminescent metal-organic frameworks (LMOFs) have been considered as a type of burgeoning materials for biological and chemical detection because of their obvious advantages, such as fast and high sensitivity, low cost, and facile manipulation []. For example, Li's group have reported two highly stable fluorescent Zr(IV)-based MOFs, BUT-14 and BUT-15 [], which exhibit potentially practical values in monitoring/sensing Fe3+ ions in water, as well as in biological systems. Another fascinating example, BUT-12 and BUT-13 reported by Zhou and Li et al. can be prospective candidates for detecting and removal of antibiotics and organic explosives in water []. The common point of two works is the high porosities of the synthesized LMOFs materials which allow the preconcentration of the target analytes in their pores, thus increasing the detecting performance. Therefore, design and synthesis LMOFs materials with large pores is an effective way to improve the sensing ability of such materials [].

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">In previous work, large numbers of LMOFs have been constructed for the luminescent sensing of divalent transition metal ions, such as Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Pb<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Hg<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> []. However, the reports of MOFs as chemical sensors for detecting trivalent metal ions are rare []. For instance, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions is one of the most essential elements for humans because it can influence electron transfer and oxygen metabolism processes in DNA and RNA synthesis []. However, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion is also a common inorganic pollutant. Excessive Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> in drinking water could result in a number of problems related to human health, such as hepatic cirrhosis and hereditary hemochromatosis []. Therefore, the development of rapid and effective chemical sensors for the detection of trace amounts of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> is highly desirable.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In previous work, large numbers of LMOFs have been constructed for the luminescent sensing of divalent transition metal ions, such as Cu2+, Pb2+ and Hg2+ []. However, the reports of MOFs as chemical sensors for detecting trivalent metal ions are rare []. For instance, Fe3+ ions is one of the most essential elements for humans because it can influence electron transfer and oxygen metabolism processes in DNA and RNA synthesis []. However, Fe3+ ion is also a common inorganic pollutant. Excessive Fe3+ in drinking water could result in a number of problems related to human health, such as hepatic cirrhosis and hereditary hemochromatosis []. Therefore, the development of rapid and effective chemical sensors for the detection of trace amounts of Fe3+ is highly desirable.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Motivated by above mentioned aspects, we successfully constructed a luminescent metal-organic framework [CdL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·1DMF·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, L = 1-(4-carboxyphenyl)-5-methyl-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole-3-carboxylic acid, DMF = <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide) which contains helical SBUs with <ce:bold>etb</ce:bold> topology. [] The choice of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> as chemical sensor for detecting Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> was based on the following two considerations: 1) Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits excellent fluorescence intensity and is favorable for the detection of metal ions. 2) Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses a large 1D hexagonal channel which could allow the preconcentration of the target analytes, thus increasing the detecting performance. As expected, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was demonstrated to be a good sensor for the quantitative detection of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> with high selectivity (Ksv = 3.5 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Motivated by above mentioned aspects, we successfully constructed a luminescent metal-organic framework [CdL(H2O)]⋅1DMF⋅1.5H2O (1, L=1-(4-carboxyphenyl)-5-methyl-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole-3-carboxylic acid, DMF=N,N-dimethylformamide) which contains helical SBUs with etb topology. [] The choice of compound 1 as chemical sensor for detecting Fe3+ was based on the following two considerations: 1) Compound 1 exhibits excellent fluorescence intensity and is favorable for the detection of metal ions. 2) Compound 1 possesses a large 1D hexagonal channel which could allow the preconcentration of the target analytes, thus increasing the detecting performance. As expected, compound 1 was demonstrated to be a good sensor for the quantitative detection of Fe3+ with high selectivity (Ksv=3.5×104).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is synthesized by Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L under solvothermal conditions at 85 °C for 24 h []. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> confirms high purity of the synthesized samples (Fig. S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurement indicates that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be stable up to about 350 °C with approximately 22% weight loss observed before 200 °C due to the removal of guest molecules and coordinated water (Fig. S2).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 is synthesized by Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O and H2L under solvothermal conditions at 85°C for 24h []. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of compound 1 confirms high purity of the synthesized samples (Fig. S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurement indicates that compound 1 can be stable up to about 350°C with approximately 22% weight loss observed before 200°C due to the removal of guest molecules and coordinated water (Fig. S2).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the trigonal crystal system with the space group of <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>-3. As shown in a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, each Cd(II) atoms is six coordinated by two carboxylate groups, one nitrogen atom and terminal water molecule from three ligands and forms an infinite helical rod-shaped metal chain, which can be simplified as the edge sharing triangle geometry. Then the rod further connects with the others through H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L ligands to generate a 3D framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the trigonal crystal system with the space group of R-3. As shown in a, each Cd(II) atoms is six coordinated by two carboxylate groups, one nitrogen atom and terminal water molecule from three ligands and forms an infinite helical rod-shaped metal chain, which can be simplified as the edge sharing triangle geometry. Then the rod further connects with the others through H2L ligands to generate a 3D framework.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">From a topological point of view, the position of nitrogen atoms can be considered as located at the vetices of a triangle and the position of N atom can be treated as a 3-c node, therefore the total framework of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses <ce:bold>etb</ce:bold> topology with a Schläfli symbol of (8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>). Similar to the structure of MOF-74 [], there exists a one-dimensional hexagonal channel with a diameter of 6.8 Å considering the van der Waals radius along [001] directions (b and c). As shown in b, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also possesses two types of helical metal chains with opposite helical directions (left and right-handed) running along the c axis (b). As represented in d, the overall structure possesses only one kind of tile of [8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From a topological point of view, the position of nitrogen atoms can be considered as located at the vetices of a triangle and the position of N atom can be treated as a 3-c node, therefore the total framework of compound 1 possesses etb topology with a Schläfli symbol of (83). Similar to the structure of MOF-74 [], there exists a one-dimensional hexagonal channel with a diameter of 6.8Å considering the van der Waals radius along [001] directions (b and c). As shown in b, compound 1 also possesses two types of helical metal chains with opposite helical directions (left and right-handed) running along the c axis (b). As represented in d, the overall structure possesses only one kind of tile of [83].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The solid-state luminescent property of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was carried out at ambient temperature. As shown in a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits fluorescent emissions at 335 nm upon excitation at 300 nm. Then the fluorescent properties of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in different solvents like DMF, <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-dimethylacetamide (DMA), acetone, acetonitrile, dioxane and ethanol were investigated. It was found that the fluorescent emissions have largely solvent dependence. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits excellent fluorescence intensity in DMF. However, a certain degree of fluorescent quenching was observed in other solvents (Fig. S4). Therefore, we select DMF as the solvent for the following fluorescence detecting tests. Considering the excellent fluorescence intensity and the large hexagonal channel of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been investigated as a potential fluorescence sensor for metal cations. Seven kinds of metal cations (Li<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Mg<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, In<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, Al<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>) were selected to evaluate the detecting performance of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. As shown in b, the luminescence intensity of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in Al<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> slightly enhance, those in Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> decrease obviously, especially in Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, while the other metal cations shown negligible quenching effect. Furthermore, the quenching efficiency was calculated by using the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation (<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>) = <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf>[Q] + 1, where <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>I</ce:italic> are the fluorescence intensities before and after the addition of the analytes, Q is the molar concentration of the analytes and <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> is the quenching constant (M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). As shown in c, d and Fig. S5, the Stern-Volmer plots for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> are nearly linear at low concentration (R<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> = 0.994), while upon the plots subsequently diverge from linearity which might be ascribed to self-absorption or energy-transfer process []. The <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> value of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> towards Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> and Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> is 3.5 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 3.9 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively (Figs. S5 and S6). It is worth mentioning that the <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> value of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> towards Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> surpass some MOFs materials (Table S3). [] Moreover, the regenerative performance is very important for a luminescence sensor when the cost of synthesis material is considered, so the recyclability of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was further studied. After five cycles of luminescence detecting experiments, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> still maintains the high luminescence intensity and detecting performance, which indicates the recyclability of the material (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The PXRD patterns of the samples after detecting tests further demonstrate the commendable practicability of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Fig. S7). These results indicate that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a recyclable luminescent sensor for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions with high selectivity and sensitivity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The solid-state luminescent property of compound 1 was carried out at ambient temperature. As shown in a, compound 1 exhibits fluorescent emissions at 335nm upon excitation at 300nm. Then the fluorescent properties of compound 1 dispersed in different solvents like DMF, N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA), acetone, acetonitrile, dioxane and ethanol were investigated. It was found that the fluorescent emissions have largely solvent dependence. Compound 1 exhibits excellent fluorescence intensity in DMF. However, a certain degree of fluorescent quenching was observed in other solvents (Fig. S4). Therefore, we select DMF as the solvent for the following fluorescence detecting tests. Considering the excellent fluorescence intensity and the large hexagonal channel of compound 1, compound 1 has been investigated as a potential fluorescence sensor for metal cations. Seven kinds of metal cations (Li+, Zn2+, Mg2+, In3+, Al3+, Cu2+, Fe3+) were selected to evaluate the detecting performance of compound 1. As shown in b, the luminescence intensity of compound 1 in Al3+ slightly enhance, those in Cu2+ and Fe3+ decrease obviously, especially in Fe3+, while the other metal cations shown negligible quenching effect. Furthermore, the quenching efficiency was calculated by using the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I)=K SV[Q]+1, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after the addition of the analytes, Q is the molar concentration of the analytes and K SV is the quenching constant (M-1). As shown in c, d and Fig. S5, the Stern-Volmer plots for Fe3+ are nearly linear at low concentration (R2=0.994), while upon the plots subsequently diverge from linearity which might be ascribed to self-absorption or energy-transfer process []. The K SV value of compound 1 towards Fe3+ and Cu2+ is 3.5×104M-1 and 3.9×103M-1, respectively (Figs. S5 and S6). It is worth mentioning that the K SV value of compound 1 towards Fe3+ surpass some MOFs materials (Table S3). [] Moreover, the regenerative performance is very important for a luminescence sensor when the cost of synthesis material is considered, so the recyclability of compound 1 was further studied. After five cycles of luminescence detecting experiments, compound 1 still maintains the high luminescence intensity and detecting performance, which indicates the recyclability of the material ( ). The PXRD patterns of the samples after detecting tests further demonstrate the commendable practicability of compound 1 (Fig. S7). These results indicate that compound 1 is a recyclable luminescent sensor for Fe3+ ions with high selectivity and sensitivity.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In summary, a Cd-based metal-organic framework with helical metal chains SBUs has been successfully synthesized. Due to the excellent fluorescence intensity and the large 1D hexagonal channels which allow the preconcentration of the target analytes and increasing the detecting performance, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits effective detecting performance for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> in DMF solution. Moreover, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be regenerated and display good recyclability for the detection of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>. Consequently, design and synthesis of such kinds of recyclable luminescent sensors are highly desirable for the detection processes of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> in the field of environment monitoring.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, a Cd-based metal-organic framework with helical metal chains SBUs has been successfully synthesized. Due to the excellent fluorescence intensity and the large 1D hexagonal channels which allow the preconcentration of the target analytes and increasing the detecting performance, compound 1 exhibits effective detecting performance for Fe3+ in DMF solution. Moreover, compound 1 can be regenerated and display good recyclability for the detection of Fe3+. Consequently, design and synthesis of such kinds of recyclable luminescent sensors are highly desirable for the detection processes of Fe3+ in the field of environment monitoring.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0030">Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:e-component id="ec0005">
<ce:caption id="ca0020">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">Supporting Information</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">A luminescent 3D metal-organic framework, [CdL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·1DMF·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, L = 1-(4-carboxyphenyl)-5-methyl-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole-3-carboxylic acid, DMF = <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide), has been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The overall structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains hexagonal channels and is constructed by helical SBUs with <ce:bold>etb</ce:bold> topology. Interestingly, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits good fluorescence intensity in DMF and can be quenched by trace amounts of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions. The Ksv values of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> towards Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>can reach up to 3.5 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> which surpass some MOFs materials. More importantly, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is also a recyclable luminescent sensor which can be potentially applied in detecting Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>.</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is synthesized by Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L under solvothermal conditions at 85 °C for 24 h []. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> confirms high purity of the synthesized samples (Fig. S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurement indicates that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be stable up to about 350 °C with approximately 22% weight loss observed before 200 °C due to the removal of guest molecules and coordinated water (Fig. S2).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The solid-state luminescent property of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was carried out at ambient temperature. As shown in a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits fluorescent emissions at 335 nm upon excitation at 300 nm. Then the fluorescent properties of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in different solvents like DMF, <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-dimethylacetamide (DMA), acetone, acetonitrile, dioxane and ethanol were investigated. It was found that the fluorescent emissions have largely solvent dependence. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits excellent fluorescence intensity in DMF. However, a certain degree of fluorescent quenching was observed in other solvents (Fig. S4). Therefore, we select DMF as the solvent for the following fluorescence detecting tests. Considering the excellent fluorescence intensity and the large hexagonal channel of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been investigated as a potential fluorescence sensor for metal cations. Seven kinds of metal cations (Li<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Mg<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, In<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, Al<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>) were selected to evaluate the detecting performance of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. As shown in b, the luminescence intensity of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in Al<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> slightly enhance, those in Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> decrease obviously, especially in Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, while the other metal cations shown negligible quenching effect. Furthermore, the quenching efficiency was calculated by using the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation (<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>) = <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf>[Q] + 1, where <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>I</ce:italic> are the fluorescence intensities before and after the addition of the analytes, Q is the molar concentration of the analytes and <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> is the quenching constant (M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). As shown in c, d and Fig. S5, the Stern-Volmer plots for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> are nearly linear at low concentration (R<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> = 0.994), while upon the plots subsequently diverge from linearity which might be ascribed to self-absorption or energy-transfer process []. The <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> value of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> towards Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> and Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> is 3.5 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 3.9 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively (Figs. S5 and S6). It is worth mentioning that the <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> value of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> towards Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> surpass some MOFs materials (Table S3). [] Moreover, the regenerative performance is very important for a luminescence sensor when the cost of synthesis material is considered, so the recyclability of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was further studied. After five cycles of luminescence detecting experiments, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> still maintains the high luminescence intensity and detecting performance, which indicates the recyclability of the material (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The PXRD patterns of the samples after detecting tests further demonstrate the commendable practicability of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Fig. S7). These results indicate that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a recyclable luminescent sensor for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions with high selectivity and sensitivity.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A luminescent 3D metal-organic framework, [CdL(H2O)]⋅1DMF⋅1.5H2O (1, L=1-(4-carboxyphenyl)-5-methyl-2,5-dihydro-1H-pyrazole-3-carboxylic acid, DMF=N,N-dimethylformamide), has been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The overall structure of 1 contains hexagonal channels and is constructed by helical SBUs with etb topology. Interestingly, compound 1 exhibits good fluorescence intensity in DMF and can be quenched by trace amounts of Fe3+ ions. The Ksv values of compound 1 towards Fe3+can reach up to 3.5×104 which surpass some MOFs materials. More importantly, compound 1 is also a recyclable luminescent sensor which can be potentially applied in detecting Fe3+.

Compound 1 is synthesized by Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O and H2L under solvothermal conditions at 85°C for 24h []. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of compound 1 confirms high purity of the synthesized samples (Fig. S1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurement indicates that compound 1 can be stable up to about 350°C with approximately 22% weight loss observed before 200°C due to the removal of guest molecules and coordinated water (Fig. S2).

The solid-state luminescent property of compound 1 was carried out at ambient temperature. As shown in a, compound 1 exhibits fluorescent emissions at 335nm upon excitation at 300nm. Then the fluorescent properties of compound 1 dispersed in different solvents like DMF, N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA), acetone, acetonitrile, dioxane and ethanol were investigated. It was found that the fluorescent emissions have largely solvent dependence. Compound 1 exhibits excellent fluorescence intensity in DMF. However, a certain degree of fluorescent quenching was observed in other solvents (Fig. S4). Therefore, we select DMF as the solvent for the following fluorescence detecting tests. Considering the excellent fluorescence intensity and the large hexagonal channel of compound 1, compound 1 has been investigated as a potential fluorescence sensor for metal cations. Seven kinds of metal cations (Li+, Zn2+, Mg2+, In3+, Al3+, Cu2+, Fe3+) were selected to evaluate the detecting performance of compound 1. As shown in b, the luminescence intensity of compound 1 in Al3+ slightly enhance, those in Cu2+ and Fe3+ decrease obviously, especially in Fe3+, while the other metal cations shown negligible quenching effect. Furthermore, the quenching efficiency was calculated by using the Stern-Volmer (SV) equation (I 0/I)=K SV[Q]+1, where I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities before and after the addition of the analytes, Q is the molar concentration of the analytes and K SV is the quenching constant (M-1). As shown in c, d and Fig. S5, the Stern-Volmer plots for Fe3+ are nearly linear at low concentration (R2=0.994), while upon the plots subsequently diverge from linearity which might be ascribed to self-absorption or energy-transfer process []. The K SV value of compound 1 towards Fe3+ and Cu2+ is 3.5×104M-1 and 3.9×103M-1, respectively (Figs. S5 and S6). It is worth mentioning that the K SV value of compound 1 towards Fe3+ surpass some MOFs materials (Table S3). [] Moreover, the regenerative performance is very important for a luminescence sensor when the cost of synthesis material is considered, so the recyclability of compound 1 was further studied. After five cycles of luminescence detecting experiments, compound 1 still maintains the high luminescence intensity and detecting performance, which indicates the recyclability of the material ( ). The PXRD patterns of the samples after detecting tests further demonstrate the commendable practicability of compound 1 (Fig. S7). These results indicate that compound 1 is a recyclable luminescent sensor for Fe3+ ions with high selectivity and sensitivity.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="ca0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Single-crystal structure for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: (a) topology simplification of the metal chain and the ligand; (b) ball and stick model of 3D framework of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> viewed along the [001] direction. Left: view of helical metal chains with opposite handedness; right: the one-dimensional hexagonal channel with a diameter of 6.8 Å considering the van der Waals radius; (c) space-filling view of the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> along the [001] direction; (d) topological features of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displayed by tiling. Color code: carbon: gray; nitrogen: blue; oxygen: red; cadmium: green. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="al0005" role="short">Fig. 1</ce:alt-text>

</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Single-crystal structure for compound 1: (a) topology simplification of the metal chain and the ligand; (b) ball and stick model of 3D framework of compound 1 viewed along the [001] direction. Left: view of helical metal chains with opposite handedness; right: the one-dimensional hexagonal channel with a diameter of 6.8Å considering the van der Waals radius; (c) space-filling view of the structure of 1 along the [001] direction; (d) topological features of 1 displayed by tiling. Color code: carbon: gray; nitrogen: blue; oxygen: red; cadmium: green. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)  Fig. 1

<ce:caption id="ca0010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">Fluorescence detecting tests: (a) the solid-state excitation (dot line) and emission (solid line) spectra of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; (b) fluorescence intensity comparison of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> upon addition of various metal cations at 1.0 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> M; (c) the emission spectra of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in DMF solution (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 300 nm) with incremental addition of the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion DMF solution (1.0 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> M, from 0 mmol/L to 0.26 mmol/L); (d) the Stern-Volmer plot of (I<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/I)-1 versus Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> concentration.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  Fluorescence detecting tests: (a) the solid-state excitation (dot line) and emission (solid line) spectra of compound 1; (b) fluorescence intensity comparison of compound 1 upon addition of various metal cations at 1.0×10-2M; (c) the emission spectra of compound 1 in DMF solution (λex=300nm) with incremental addition of the Fe3+ ion DMF solution (1.0×10-2M, from 0mmol/L to 0.26mmol/L); (d) the Stern-Volmer plot of (I0/I)-1 versus Fe3+ concentration.
